Accommodation and repair of a UV photoproduct in DNA at different rotational settings on the nucleosome surface.Journal of Biological ChemistryVol. 285Issue 50PreviewVOLUME 280 (2005) PAGES 40051–40057 Full-Text PDF Open Access In eukaryotes, DNA is organized in chromatin structures within the cell nucleus. The chromatin serves a dual purpose, tight DNA packing within the nucleus and organization of dynamic processes such as DNA transcription, replication, and repair. Of these, DNA repair protects genomic integrity from DNA-damaging agents and is vital for cell survival (1Friedberg E.C. Walker G.C. Siede W. DNA Repair and Mutagenesis. 2nd Ed. American Society for Microbiology, 1995Google Scholar). Indeed, occasional failures in DNA repair can lead to aging and to multiple diseases, including cancer (2Hanawalt P.C. Mutat. Res. 1998; 400: 117-125Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar, 3Hoeijmakers J.H. Nature. 2001; 411: 366-374Crossref PubMed Scopus (3149) Google Scholar). When DNA is irradiated with UV light, adjacent pyrimidines can form stable covalent bonds, yielding cis-syn cyclobutane-pyrimidine dimers (CPDs). 5The abbreviations used are: CPDcis-syn cyclobutane-pyrimidine dimerCTDcis-syn cyclobutane-thymine dimerGREglucocorticoid response elementNERnucleotide excision repair·OHhydroxyl radicalT4 endo VT4 endonuclease V. A common UV lesion caused by exposure to direct sunlight, CPDs can lead to skin cancer, one of the most common forms of cancer (4Cleaver J.E. Crowley E. Front. Biosci. 2002; 7: d1024-d1043Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The CPD lesion can stall DNA replication (5Li Y. Dutta S. Doublie S. Bdour H.M. Taylor J.S. Ellenberger T. Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol. 2004; 11: 784-790Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar) and transcription (6Tommasi S. Swiderski P.M. Tu Y. Kaplan B.E. Pfeifer G.P. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 15693-15703Crossref PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar) and disrupt DNA interactions with other proteins that regulate gene expression (6Tommasi S. Swiderski P.M. Tu Y. Kaplan B.E. Pfeifer G.P. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 15693-15703Crossref PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar). Each of these events can lead to genetic instability. cis-syn cyclobutane-pyrimidine dimer cis-syn cyclobutane-thymine dimer glucocorticoid response element nucleotide excision repair hydroxyl radical T4 endonuclease V. The effect of chromatin structure on repair of UV damage was first implicated by the findings of Wilkins and Hart (7Wilkins R.J. Hart R.W. Nature. 1974; 247: 35-36Crossref PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar). These authors showed that UV-induced lesions in permeable human cells are removed more slowly from DNA that is less accessible to lesion-specific nucleases in chromatin. It was then found that newly repaired DNA in UV-irradiated human fibroblasts is initially more accessible to exogenous nucleases than bulk DNA in chromatin (8Smerdon M.J. Tlsty T.D. Lieberman M.W. Biochemistry. 1978; 17: 2377-2386Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar) and that nucleosome rearrangement occurs in these regions (9Smerdon M.J. Lieberman M.W. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1978; 75: 4238-4241Crossref PubMed Scopus (181) Google Scholar). Studies with a yeast mini-chromosome showed that repair of CPDs is faster in nucleosome-free segments of DNA, being highest in the transcribed strand of a selectable gene and correlating with transcription rate in different regions of the mini-chromosome (10Bedoyan J. Gupta R. Thoma F. Smerdon M.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 5996-6005Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 11Smerdon M.J. Bedoyan J. Thoma F. Nucleic Acids Res. 1990; 18: 2045-2051Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar, 12Smerdon M.J. Thoma F. Cell. 1990; 61: 675-684Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (166) Google Scholar). In addition, high resolution analysis of NER in this mini-chromosome demonstrated modulation of repair by nucleosomes in the nontranscribed strand of the selectable gene such that slow repair occurred within the “internal protected region” of the nucleosomes and fast repair occurred in linker DNA (13Wellinger R.E. Thoma F. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 5046-5056Crossref PubMed Scopus (127) Google Scholar). Interestingly, a study of CPD repair rates at the level of individual bases showed that in some cases the repair rates can vary almost 10-fold even when lesion sites are less than one turn of the DNA helix apart (14Tornaletti S. Pfeifer G.P. Science. 1994; 263: 1436-1438Crossref PubMed Scopus (291) Google Scholar). Similar to studies in whole cells, in vitro studies with extracts from human fibroblasts showed that nucleosomes can reduce repair rates of CPDs by 6–9-fold relative to free DNA (15Wang Z.G. Wu X.H. Friedberg E.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 22472-22478Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In addition, work with a site-specific 6–4 photoproduct (T(6–4)T) showed there is an ∼10-fold difference in the initial damage excision rates between naked DNA and DNA bound to nucleosomes, using both extracts from HeLa cells and a reconstituted human excision complex (16Hara R. Mo J. Sancar A. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2000; 20: 9173-9181Crossref PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar). Furthermore, in vitro studies with SV 40 mini-chromosomes and different cell extracts showed that DNA interaction with nucleosomes can inhibit repair rates of UV lesions by 4–6-fold relative to free DNA (17Sugasawa K. Masutani C. Hanaoka F. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 9098-9104Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Interestingly, extracts from large nuclei of Xenopus oocytes showed only a 2-fold difference in repair rates between free DNA and nucleosomes containing a single cis-syn cyclobutane-thymine dimer (CTD) that faced away from the histone surface (Ref. 18Kosmoski J.V. Ackerman E.J. Smerdon M.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001; 98: 10113-10118Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar and Fig. 1). (It is important to note that these nuclei have exceptionally large quantities of nuclear proteins that facilitate fast DNA synthesis at the onset of embryogenesis (19Ackerman E.J. Iakoucheva L.M. Methods. 2000; 22: 188-193Crossref PubMed Scopus (6) Google Scholar)). In summary, depending on the sequence and cell type, chromatin proteins can block DNA repair rates by 2- to 10-fold relative to free DNA. Nucleosomes are the primary structural unit of the chromatin hierarchy (20Wolffe A.P. Hayes J.J. Nucleic Acids Res. 1999; 27: 711-720Crossref PubMed Scopus (436) Google Scholar). Nucleosome core particles contain 147 base pairs of DNA wrapped 1.65 turns around a histone octamer 7 nm in diameter (21Luger K. Mader A.W. Richmond R.K. Sargent D.F. Richmond T.J. Nature. 1997; 389: 251-260Crossref PubMed Scopus (6925) Google Scholar). A CTD lesion causes a sharp 30° bend toward the major grove of DNA and a 9° unwinding of the strand containing the lesion (22Park H. Zhang K. Ren Y. Nadji S. Sinha N. Taylor J.S. Kang C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2002; 99: 15965-15970Crossref PubMed Scopus (197) Google Scholar). However, CPDs do not displace DNA from histones, and nucleosomes containing CPDs can be readily isolated or prepared (23Gale J.M. Nissen K.A. Smerdon M.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 6644-6648Crossref PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar, 24Kosmoski J.V. Smerdon M.J. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 9485-9494Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar). Furthermore, DNA interactions within nucleosomes do not significantly affect the overall frequency of CPD formation, because there is only an ∼1.5-fold difference in CPD yield between linker DNA and DNA bound to nucleosomes (25Gale J.M. Smerdon M.J. Photochem. Photobiol. 1990; 51: 411-417Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar, 26Mitchell D.L. Nguyen T.D. Cleaver J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 5353-5356Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Rather, DNA interactions within nucleosomes affect the site of the lesion (23Gale J.M. Nissen K.A. Smerdon M.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 6644-6648Crossref PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar). CPD lesions show specific preference for DNA sites that face away from the histone surface (i.e. CTD-OUT in Fig. 1) (23Gale J.M. Nissen K.A. Smerdon M.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 6644-6648Crossref PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar). These sites have greater rotational freedom in the phosphate backbone, which is crucial in bringing adjacent pyrimidines to the correct angle to form CPDs (27Rao S.N. Keepers J.W. Kollman P. Nucleic Acids Res. 1984; 12: 4789-4807Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). Interestingly, when free genomic DNA containing randomly distributed CPDs is assembled into nucleosomes, the CPDs are found preferentially facing away from the histone surface (Fig. 1) (28Suquet C. Smerdon M.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 23755-23757Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Thus, there is an energy penalty in burying CPD lesions on the histone surface (29Mann D.B. Springer D.L. Smerdon M.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 2215-2220Crossref PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar). At this point, it remains to be seen whether CPDs change the DNA rotational setting on all nucleosome surfaces regardless of location or sequence and whether such a change can affect repair of this damage. In this study, using organic synthesis (24Kosmoski J.V. Smerdon M.J. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 9485-9494Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar) we have prepared CTD lesions at different positions within a short oligonucleotide sequence containing a Glucocorticoid hormone Response Element (GRE). This sequence has been used in past studies focused on DNA accessibility in a DNA-nucleosome complex (24Kosmoski J.V. Smerdon M.J. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 9485-9494Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar, 30Li Q. Wrange O. Genes Dev. 1993; 7: 2471-2482Crossref PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar, 31Li Q. Wrange O. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1995; 15: 4375-4384Crossref PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar, 32Beard B.C. Wilson S.H. Smerdon M.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2003; 100: 7465-7470Crossref PubMed Scopus (124) Google Scholar). The GRE sequence containing a CTD lesion was bracketed by multiple repeats of the TG motif (33Shrader T.E. Crothers D.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1989; 86: 7418-7422Crossref PubMed Scopus (305) Google Scholar) in an attempt to modulate the rotational setting of CTDs near the nucleosome dyad axis (31Li Q. Wrange O. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1995; 15: 4375-4384Crossref PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar). We found that, within strong nucleosome positioning sequences like the TG motif, CTDs are accommodated by the intrinsic DNA rotational setting on the nucleosome surface that is similar to undamaged DNA. Furthermore, we have shown that different DNA rotational settings on the nucleosome surface have relatively small effects (up to 1.5-fold) on the repair rates of CTD lesions in nuclear extracts from Xenopus laevis oocytes. Synthetic DNA Substrates—Cis-syn cyclobutyl-thymidine dimers were prepared as phosphoramidites by organic synthesis, as previously described (24Kosmoski J.V. Smerdon M.J. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 9485-9494Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar), and incorporated into oligonucleotides at the desired sequence by solid phase synthesis. The CTDs were incorporated into a GRE sequence (underlined) surrounded by multiple repeats of the TG motif (A/T)3NN(G/C)3NN: fragment 5R, 5′-TTG TAC ATT ATG TTC TAG CCT GTA ACA GCC TGT TAG AGC CTG TAA CTC GGT GTT AGA GCC TGT AAC TCG GTG TTA GAG CCT GTA ACT-3′. Four different 5R fragments were prepared, depending on the desired CTD position. For the CTD-IN fragment (Fig. 1), the fragment 5R had only one CTD site at the first TT site (shown in bold, starting from the 5′-end). For the CTD-OUT fragment (Fig. 1), the fragment 5R had only one CTD site at the second underlined TT site (shown in bold starting from the 5′-end). For CTD-IN-OUT, fragment 5R had a CTD at each of the underlined TT sites. Finally, we also prepared 5R fragment without the CTD lesion at either of the two TT sites (UND fragment). In addition, we prepared the following three fragments, fragment 3L: 5′-GTT ACA GGC TCT AAC ACC GAG TTA CAG GCT CTA ACA CCG AGT TAC AGG CTC TAA-3′; fragment 5L: 5′-TGT TAG AGC CTG TAA CTC GGT GTT AGA GCC TGT AAC TCG GTG TTA GAG CCT GTA ACT CGG TGA-3′; fragment 3R: 5′-B AGT TAC AGG C TC TAA CAC CG A GTT A CA GGC TCT AA C ACC G AG TTA CAG GC T CTA A CA GGCTGT TA C AGG C TA GAACAT AA T GTA C AA TCA CCG-3′. The fragments 5R and 3R and fragments 5L and 3L are complementary. Underlined on fragments 5L and 3R are six base pair overhangs that serve as “sticky ends” during the ligation reaction, described later. The fragment 3R has a blocking group (B = methoxyl trityl amine or n-buthylamine) on the 5′-end to prevent phosphorylation by the 5′-kinase. Each of the fragments was purified by reverse phase high pressure liquid chromatography, dissolved in TE buffer (10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 1 mm EDTA), and stored in -80 °C. The fragments containing CTD sites were used within 1.5 years from the day of synthesis. DNA Ligation—The four fragments shown above were ligated to prepare the final 150-bp oligonucleotides as previously described (34Tullius T.D. Dombroski B.A. Churchill M.E. Kam L. Methods Enzymol. 1987; 155: 537-558Crossref PubMed Scopus (287) Google Scholar). The prepared full-length DNA was resuspended in TE buffer and stored under argon at -80 °C. The final oligonucleotide concentration was determined from the absorbance at 260 nm using a calculated extinction coefficient of 2.86 × 106 m-1cm-1. Digestion by CTD-specific T4 endonuclease V (T4 endo V) indicated that all fragments can be digested to ∼90% (data not shown), indicating that ∼90% of the originally synthesized CTD lesion was intact at the time of the experiment. Nucleosome Reconstitution—The 150-bp long oligonucleotides containing CTDs were reconstituted into core particles using nucleosomes prepared from chicken erythrocytes and slow dialysis from high to low salt as described earlier (24Kosmoski J.V. Smerdon M.J. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 9485-9494Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar). Briefly, reconstitution was typically carried out with 10 ng of radiolabeled DNA (0.1 pmol) and 2 μg of core particles (20 pmol) in a total volume of 50 μl. Initially, the reaction included 1 m NaCl, 1 mm EDTA, and 10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, which was first allowed to equilibrate for 30 min at 25 °C and then for 30 min at 4 °C. The reaction was dialyzed (Spectra/Por Membrane MWCO 6000–8000) against 0.6 m NaCl, 10 mm Tris (pH 7.5), 1 mm EDTA, and 0.2 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride for 4–6 h at 4 °C. Finally, the reaction was dialyzed against 50 mm NaCl, 10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 1 mm EDTA, and 0.2 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride for 4 h at 4 °C. In competitive gel-shift experiments, 100-fold less DNA and chicken erythrocyte core particles were used in the same volume, and the reconstitution protocol was identical. Products were assayed by native PAGE (6% acrylamide, 0.2% bisacrylamide in TBE), dried, and exposed to a phosphoimager screen for 24 h. The ratio of bound to free DNA with and without CTDs at different sites was quantified by ImageQuant software (Amersham Biosciences) and used to calculate association constants (Ka = bound/free) and the change in free energy of the DNA-histone interaction (ΔΔG) as shown in Equation 1: ΔΔG =-RTln[Ka(damaged)/Ka(undamaged)]. Hydroxyl Radical Footprinting—Hydroxyl radical (·OH) footprinting was performed following earlier published procedures (34Tullius T.D. Dombroski B.A. Churchill M.E. Kam L. Methods Enzymol. 1987; 155: 537-558Crossref PubMed Scopus (287) Google Scholar). Gels were dried, exposed to PhosphorImager screens, and visualized on an Amersham Biosciences (model 455-P90) PhosphorImager. Images were analyzed with ImageQuant software (Amersham Biosciences). Xenopus Nuclear Extracts and Repair—Repair extracts were prepared from Xenopus oocyte nuclei as described earlier (19Ackerman E.J. Iakoucheva L.M. Methods. 2000; 22: 188-193Crossref PubMed Scopus (6) Google Scholar). The in vitro repair experiments were performed as previously described, with some modification (18Kosmoski J.V. Ackerman E.J. Smerdon M.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001; 98: 10113-10118Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar). Briefly, in vitro repair reactions (20–25 μl final volume) included 0.1 nm radiolabeled oligonucleotides (∼15,000 cpm), 0.7 mm dATP, 0.5 mm dTTP, dCTP, and dGTP, 0.1 nmol chicken erythrocyte core particles, 5 mg/ml ultrapure salmon sperm DNA (2.5 kb average length; Invitrogen), nuclear extract equivalent of 2 nuclei, and fresh repair buffer (8.5 mm MgCl2, 7 mm Hepes, pH 7.4, 70 mm KCl, 0.1 mm EDTA, 3 mm dithiothreitol, 10% glycerol, 1% polyvinyl-pyrrolidone 360,000). Reactions were carried out at room temperature in the dark. At each repair time, 4.0-μl aliquots of the repair reaction were combined with 16 μl of TE buffer and extracted with 30 μl of PCI (50% Tris-buffered phenol, 48% chloroform, and 2% isoamyl alcohol) to remove all proteins. DNA in the aqueous phase was ethanol precipitated, washed twice with 80% ethanol, and resuspended with 0.4 units/μl of T4 endo V in 50 mm NaCl, 25 mm sodium phosphate, pH 6.8, 10 mm EDTA, and 100 μg/ml bovine serum albumin (35Dodson M.L. Lloyd R.S. Mutat. Res. 1989; 218: 49-65Crossref PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar). Samples were assayed for CTDs by digestion with T4 endo V for 1.5 h at room temperature, followed by electrophoresis on denaturing gels (7 m urea, 10% acrylamide, 0.5% bisacrylamide, TBE). Gels were dried, exposed to PhosphorImager screens, and visualized as described above. The percentage of CTD repair at each time point was determined as a fraction of the T4 endo V cut and T4 endo V uncut bands relative to the total pixel destiny in the given lane to offset loading variations between lanes. Rotational Orientation of CTDs on the Nucleosome Surface—The reaction of DNA with hydroxyl radical (·OH) is routinely used to map the interaction between DNA-binding proteins and the DNA phosphate backbone (34Tullius T.D. Dombroski B.A. Churchill M.E. Kam L. Methods Enzymol. 1987; 155: 537-558Crossref PubMed Scopus (287) Google Scholar). We have used this reaction to compare the rotational setting (Fig. 1) of undamaged DNA on the histone surface in nucleosomes with that of DNA molecules containing CTDs at different sites 5 nucleotides apart (i.e. one half turn of the DNA helix, Fig. 1). The CTD sites were positioned at the nucleosome dyad where histone-DNA interactions are strongest and the DNA helix is underwound (21Luger K. Mader A.W. Richmond R.K. Sargent D.F. Richmond T.J. Nature. 1997; 389: 251-260Crossref PubMed Scopus (6925) Google Scholar). The ·OHs cut the phosphate backbone essentially independent of DNA sequence, and the cuts can be analyzed as distinct bands on a sequencing gel (Fig. 2). As shown in Figs. 2 and 3, reaction of free DNA with ·OHs yields a series of bands of approximately uniform intensity. On the other hand, when this DNA is wrapped around histones in nucleosomes, it yields a series of bands that have a periodic variation in band intensity (Figs. 2 and 3). These periodic variations reflect the periodicity of exposure of DNA phosphates on the histone surface (34Tullius T.D. Dombroski B.A. Churchill M.E. Kam L. Methods Enzymol. 1987; 155: 537-558Crossref PubMed Scopus (287) Google Scholar). As we previously observed (24Kosmoski J.V. Smerdon M.J. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 9485-9494Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar), when the phosphate backbone is cut at CTD sites, the two bases remain attached by the cyclobutane bond holding the adjacent bases together. Thus, there is a band missing at the site of the CTD lesion, and the n+1 band is approximately double in intensity (Figs. 2 and 3). These gaps at CTD sites make them easy to find on the ·OH gels (24Kosmoski J.V. Smerdon M.J. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 9485-9494Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar). In addition, the individual bands can be identified by comparing their mobility with lanes containing Maxam-Gilbert reactions for G sites (34Tullius T.D. Dombroski B.A. Churchill M.E. Kam L. Methods Enzymol. 1987; 155: 537-558Crossref PubMed Scopus (287) Google Scholar).FIGURE 3CTD lesions can adjust to different rotational settings dictated by the TG motif. A, superimposed scans of ·OH reaction for undamaged (black) and CTD-IN-OUT (red) sample as shown in Fig. 1. B, deletion of 3 base pairs in the sticky ends region (see “Materials and Methods”) results in a change in the CTD rotational setting as dictated by the TG motif.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) We find that undamaged DNA and DNA with different CTD lesions show similar patterns in mobility and relative intensity in the ·OH-induced cuts. Preserved relative intensity between the ·OH cut patterns indicates that CTD sites do not affect DNA rotational setting relative to the nucleosome surface. The similarity in mobility of ·OH-induced cuts with minimal and maximal intensity indicates that CTD lesions do not cause extensive unwinding or stretching of the DNA helix. These results indicate that CTD sites can be buried at the surface (Fig. 3, CTD-IN), fully exposed to the surrounding media (CTD-OUT), or simultaneously buried and fully exposed (CTD-IN-OUT). Thus, CTDs do not cause a large change in interaction between the DNA phosphate backbone and the nucleosome surface, even though this lesion in free DNA causes 30° bending in the long axis and a 9° twist in base pairing (22Park H. Zhang K. Ren Y. Nadji S. Sinha N. Taylor J.S. Kang C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2002; 99: 15965-15970Crossref PubMed Scopus (197) Google Scholar). We also prepared oligonucleotide fragments with CTDs at different positions relative to the phased TG motifs by deleting nucleotides at the sticky end of the four DNA fragments that were used to prepare the full-length 150-bp DNA (see “Materials and Methods”). A similar strategy was used by Li and Wrange (31Li Q. Wrange O. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1995; 15: 4375-4384Crossref PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar) to change the rotational setting of the GRE element on the surface of nucleosomes. As shown in Fig. 3, CTDs can adapt to different rotational settings of the DNA molecule on the nucleosome surface when dictated by TG motifs. For example, when DNA fragments have two CTDs 5 nucleotides apart, they can be positioned with one CTD facing precisely away (CTD-OUT) and one CTD facing precisely toward (CTD-IN) the histones (Fig. 3A). On the other hand, these two CTD lesions can also be positioned to face in more of a tangential direction on the nucleosome surface when shifted 3 nucleotides relative to the beginning of the TG motifs (Fig. 3B). Change in Free Energy of DNA-Histone Interactions Caused by CTD Lesions in Different Positions—Together with the ·OH footprinting experiments, the differences in DNA-histone interaction can be described by the differences in free energy of interaction (Equation 1, ΔΔG values). All oligonucleotides containing CTDs can be fully reconstituted in nucleosomes (Fig. 4A); however, when the reconstitution reaction is diluted 100-fold, DNA molecules with CTDs at different sites show a difference in the extent of reconstitution (Fig. 4B). The relative intensity of the reconstituted band and free DNA band can be quantified and the corresponding ΔΔG values can be calculated (Equation 1). We find that one CTD facing out can destabilize DNA-histone interactions at the nucleosome surface, relative to undamaged DNA, by a change in free energy (ΔΔG) of 0.6 ± 0.12 kJ/mol. The ΔΔG for CTD-IN is close to twice that value (1.1 ± 0.2 kJ/mol), which indicates there is ∼0.5 kJ/mol in free energy penalty when the CTD is buried at the nucleosome surface. Interestingly, with DNA containing two CTDs separated by only one half turn of the DNA helix (Fig. 1, CTD-IN-OUT), the DNA-histone interactions within nucleosomes are destabilized by ΔΔG = 1.6 ± 0.3 kJ/mol, which is close to the sum of the change in free energy penalties for each lesion alone. Thus, the CTD sites act almost independently, and this is consistent with a localized disturbance in DNA-histone interaction at each CTD site. The observed changes in free energy are very similar to the values we reported previously for randomly positioned CPD lesions within 5 S ribosomal DNA (TABLE ONE and Ref. 29Mann D.B. Springer D.L. Smerdon M.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 2215-2220Crossref PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar). Although apparently small, these differences are significant for the majority of genomic DNA sequences, where rotational setting is supported by ΔΔG values closer to 1 kJ/mol (36Widlund H.R. Cao H. Simonsson S. Magnusson E. Simonsson T. Nielsen P.E. Kahn J.D. Crothers D.M. Kubista M. J. Mol. Biol. 1997; 267: 807-817Crossref PubMed Scopus (166) Google Scholar).TABLE ONEChange in free energy of DNA-histone interactions relative to undamaged DNA All values were calculated using Equation 1 as shown in Figure 4B. The repair reactions for free DNA and nucleosome DNA were identical and run in parallel (see “Materials and Methods”). The progress of the repair reaction was monitored on a denaturing gel by following the disappearance of the T4-cut band and appearance of the T4-uncut band (Fig. 5 and “Materials and Methods”). To further understand the mechanism of promoter escape by RNA polymerase II, we have systematically investigated the effect of core promoter sequence on the rate of transcript synthesis in vitro. Chimeric and mutant promoters were made by swapping sequences between the human interleukin-2 promoter and the adenovirus major late promoter, which exhibit different rates of transcript synthesis. Kinetic studies at these promoters revealed that sequences downstream of the start sites set the rate of transcript synthesis. Specifically, the sequences at +2 and +7/+8 are critical for determining the rate; when either +2 is a C (nontemplate strand) or +7/+8 is a TT (nontemplate strand), transcript synthesis is slow. At +7/+8, the thermodynamic stability of the RNA:DNA hybrid controls the overall rate of transcript synthesis. Our data support a model in which the rate-limiting step during transcript synthesis by RNA polymerase II in vitro occurs at the point in the reaction at which early ternary complexes transform into elongation complexes.

Lipid-binding proteins exhibit important functions in lipid transport, cellular signaling, gene transcription, and cytoprotection. Their functional analogues in nematodes are nematode polyprotein allergens/antigens and fatty acid and retinoid-binding proteins. This work describes a novel 55-kDa protein, Ag-lbp55, purified from the parasitic nematode Ascaridia galli. By direct N-terminal sequencing, a partial amino acid sequence was obtained that allowed the design of oligonucleotide primers to obtain the full-length cDNA sequence. Sequence analysis revealed the presence of an N-terminal signal peptide of 25 amino acid residues and a FAR domain at the C terminus. Data base searches showed almost no significant homologies to other described proteins. The secondary structure of Ag-lbp55 was predominantly α-helical (65%) as shown by CD spectroscopy. It was found to bind with high affinity fatty acids (caprylic, oleic, and palmitic acid) and their fluorescent analogue dansylaminoundecanic acid. Immunolocalization showed that Ag-lbp55 is a highly abundant protein, mainly distributed in the inner hypodermis and extracellularly in the pseudocoelomatic fluid. A similar staining pattern was observed in other pathogenic nematodes, indicating the existence of similar proteins in these species. Lipid-binding proteins exhibit important functions in lipid transport, cellular signaling, gene transcription, and cytoprotection. Their functional analogues in nematodes are nematode polyprotein allergens/antigens and fatty acid and retinoid-binding proteins. This work describes a novel 55-kDa protein, Ag-lbp55, purified from the parasitic nematode Ascaridia galli. By direct N-terminal sequencing, a partial amino acid sequence was obtained that allowed the design of oligonucleotide primers to obtain the full-length cDNA sequence. Sequence analysis revealed the presence of an N-terminal signal peptide of 25 amino acid residues and a FAR domain at the C terminus. Data base searches showed almost no significant homologies to other described proteins. The secondary structure of Ag-lbp55 was predominantly α-helical (65%) as shown by CD spectroscopy. It was found to bind with high affinity fatty acids (caprylic, oleic, and palmitic acid) and their fluorescent analogue dansylaminoundecanic acid. Immunolocalization showed that Ag-lbp55 is a highly abundant protein, mainly distributed in the inner hypodermis and extracellularly in the pseudocoelomatic fluid. A similar staining pattern was observed in other pathogenic nematodes, indicating the existence of similar proteins in these species. Parasitic nematodes are the most significant helminths in terms of numbers of species and distribution, causing many serious diseases in humans and animals. Furthermore, they have a great economic impact on many agricultural products. Differences between host and parasite biochemistry present possible targets for chemotherapy and are the object of intensive research in parasitology. In parasitic nematodes, specific metabolic pathways are modified to meet their actual physicochemical environment, the host organism. Because of the low oxygen tension in the host organs and tissues, helminths show a down-regulation of enzymes from the oxygen-dependent pathways, such as β-oxidation (1Barrett J. Chowdhury N. Tada I. Perspectives on Helminthology. 2001: 309-334Google Scholar, 2Tielens A.G. Parasitol. Today. 1994; 10: 346-352Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (155) Google Scholar). They exhibit restricted lipid metabolism but contain high levels of lipid as long chain fatty acids, retinoids, and steroids (1Barrett J. Chowdhury N. Tada I. Perspectives on Helminthology. 2001: 309-334Google Scholar). The import of these metabolites from the host organism is essential for parasite survival, and consequently, the lipid transporters are possible targets for therapeutic agents (3Kennedy M.W. Kennedy M.W. Harnett W. Parasitic Nematodes: Molecular Biology, Biochemistry and Immunology. 2001: 309-330Google Scholar).The lipophilic ligands, such as long chain fatty acids, eicosanoids, retinoids, and steroids, play an important role in cellular homeostasis. Triacylglycerols are the major cell energy storage compounds. Some of the polyunsaturated fatty acids, retinoids, and steroids act as signaling molecules and take part in important cell processes such as gene transcription, cell development, inflammation, and immune response (4Noy N. Biochem. J. 2000; 348: 481-495Crossref PubMed Scopus (357) Google Scholar). As a consequence of their similar physical properties, principally hydrophobicity, these chemically and functionally different metabolites are unified into the group of “lipids.” Because the tissue and cell environment is hydrophilic, these metabolites need to be solubilized and protected from chemical damage, and their transport and function have to be tightly regulated. The lipid-binding proteins (LBPs) 4The abbreviations used are: LBPslipid-binding proteinsNPAnematode polyprotein allergens/antigensFARfatty acid and retinoid-binding proteinsDAUDAdansylaminoundecanic acidMALDI-TOFmatrix-assisted laser desorption ionization time-of-flightFABPsfatty acid-binding proteinsRACErapid amplification of cDNA ends.4The abbreviations used are: LBPslipid-binding proteinsNPAnematode polyprotein allergens/antigensFARfatty acid and retinoid-binding proteinsDAUDAdansylaminoundecanic acidMALDI-TOFmatrix-assisted laser desorption ionization time-of-flightFABPsfatty acid-binding proteinsRACErapid amplification of cDNA ends. perform the important role of lipid carriers. Recently, proteins of the LBP family, related to the oxysterol-binding protein, were identified to play a major role in intracellular lipid targeting and are also structural components of the membrane contact sites (5Loewen C.J. Roy A. Levine T.P. EMBO J. 2003; 22: 2025-2035Crossref PubMed Scopus (437) Google Scholar, 6Levine T. Although lipocalins and FABPs are small β-sheet proteins (20 and 14 kDa, respectively), albumin is a larger α-helical protein (67 kDa) (7Wilton D.C. Biochem. J. 1990; 270: 163-166Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar). Although mammalian FABPs are cytosolic and possess various tissue isoforms, lipocalins and albumin are involved in the extracellular lipid transport (8Zimmerman A.W. Veerkamp J.H. Cell. Mol. Life Sci. 2002; 59: 1096-1116Crossref PubMed Scopus (413) Google Scholar).Nematodes secrete structurally different classes of small (15-20 kDa), helical lipid-binding proteins into host tissues, referred to as nematode polyprotein allergens/antigens (NPA) and fatty acid and retinoid-binding proteins (FAR) (9Kennedy M.W. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2000; 1476: 149-164Crossref PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar, 10McDermott L. Cooper A. Kennedy M.W. Mol. Cell. The first representatives were identified as major nematode antigens (As-NPA-1 from Ascaris suum and Ov-FAR-1 from Onchocerca volvulus). They show a high affinity for amphipathic molecules, such as fatty acids and retinoids, and these features appear to be true for all members of both families (12Kennedy M.W. Brass A. McCruden A.B. Price N.C. Kelly S.M. Cooper A. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 6700-6710Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar, 13Kennedy M.W. Garside L.H. Goodrick L.E. McDermott L. Brass A. Price N.C. Kelly S.M. Biochem. 1999; 261: 569-576Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar). The completion of the genome from the model nematode Caenorhabditis elegans revealed eight FAR protein sequences, Ce-FAR-1 to 8 (11Garofalo A. Rowlinson M.C. Amambua N.A. Hughes J.M. Kelly S.M. Price N.C. Cooper A. Watson D.G. Kennedy M.W. Bradley J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 8065-8074Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). Because FAR and NPA play a critical role in the fatty acid and retinoid import from the host and their ligands are essential for parasite survival, these proteins are of great interest. Additionally, a localized decrease of such lipids may have immunomodulatory effects that compromise the host immune response (1Barrett J. Chowdhury N. Tada I. Perspectives on Helminthology. 2001: 309-334Google Scholar, 3Kennedy M.W. Kennedy M.W. Harnett W. Parasitic Nematodes: Molecular Biology, Biochemistry and Immunology. 2001: 309-330Google Scholar).In the chicken parasite, Ascaridia galli, the most abundant and prolific proteins have affinity for fatty acids. These are the NPA representative, Ag-NPA-1 (14Timanova A. Muller S. Marti T. Bankov I. Walter R.D. Eur. J. Biochem. 1999; 261: 569-576Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar, 15Jordanova R. In the present study, Ag-lbp55 was purified, and its primary and secondary structures were identified. Its affinity for long chain fatty acids was studied by fluorescence spectroscopy. Furthermore, immunolocalization was performed, indicating an extracellular localization and the presence of similar proteins in other nematode parasites.MATERIALS AND METHODSProtein Purification—Native Ag-lbp55 was purified from adult A. galli worms, as described for Ag-NPA-1 (14Timanova A. A fused quartz cell with a path length of 0.1 cm was used. The protein concentration was 12.2 μm. The spectra, measured in the far UV-region of 190-260 nm, were averages of four scans and were corrected by subtracting the base line of the buffer. They are reported as mean residue molar ellipticity ([θ]R) in degrees cm2 dmol-1. Commun. 1982; 27: 229-242Crossref Scopus (2516) Google Scholar).Peptide Sequencing—For internal sequencing, protein bands were cut out of the gel and digested with trypsin and the endoproteinases Lys-C and Asp-N (Roche Applied Science) as described (21Eckerskorn C. Lottspeich F. Electrophoresis. 1993; 14: 831-838Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar). The obtained peptides were subjected to N-terminal sequencing and MALDI-TOF analysis. Microsequencing was performed using a gas-phase sequenator Procise 492 cLC (Applied Biosystems GmbH).Nucleotide and Amino Acid Sequence—Based on the obtained N-terminal and internal peptide sequences, various combinations of degenerate oligonucleotides were designed, from the N-terminal sequence three forward primers S1, S2, and S3 and one reverse primer AS1, and from internal peptides three forward S4, S5, and S6 and four reverse primers AS2, AS3, AS4, and AS5 (TABLE ONE and Fig. 3). Total RNA was isolated from adult worms, using the TRIzol reagent (Invitrogen). Reverse transcription was performed with 4 μg of RNA, oligo(dT) primer, and Moloney-murine leukemia virus-reverse transcriptase (MBI) or Transcriptor Reverse Transcriptase (Roche Applied Science). Gene fragments were amplified from the cDNA preparation by PCR with random combinations of the forward and reverse degenerate primers, using PCR Supermix (Invitrogen). The annealing temperature was 55 °C. The PCR fragments were cloned into TOPO-TA-modified vector (pCR II, Invitrogen) and sequenced. The obtained sequence data were used to design new and specific oligonucleotide primers. Amplification with the standard PCR protocol of the ag-lbp55 gene fragment and the internal regions of the degenerated primers was performed with the specific forward and reverse primers S11, S44, AS33, and AS44 (TABLE ONE and Fig. 3). The missing 5′ and 3′ ends of the cDNA from the ag-lbp55 gene as well as the 5′- and 3′-degenerated oligonucleotide regions were isolated and sequenced using the 5′- and 3′-RACE methods, according to the manufacturer's manual (Invitrogen). The primers used for RACE experiments were S33 and S22 for the 3′-RACE and AS11 and AS22 for the 5′-RACE (TABLE ONE and Fig. 3). Molecular mass, molar extinction coefficient, and isoelectric point (pI) of the protein were estimated with the ProtParam program.Ligand Binding Experiments and Reagents—The fluorescent fatty acid analogue 11-((5-dimethylaminonaphthalene-1-sulfonyl)amino)undecanoic acid (DAUDA) was obtained from Molecular Probes (Invitrogen). The fatty acids were products of Sigma. All ligands were dissolved in ethanol in concentrations of either 1 or 0.1 mm. The concentration of DAUDA was calculated from its absorption spectra, using the corresponding molar extinction coefficient of 4.8 × 10-3 cm-1 m-1. Steady-state fluorescence was measured with a Shimadzu model RF5000 and PerkinElmer Life Sciences LS50B spectrofluorometers, equipped with a thermostatically controlled cuvette holder.Ligand binding experiments were performed with 0.1 μm Ag-lbp55 and an initial sample volume of 800 μl. Binding affinities of Ag-lbp55 for fatty acids were studied by changes in the intrinsic tryptophan emission of the protein (excitation wavelength λex of 295 nm and emission wavelength λem 340 nm). Binding of the fluorescent ligand DAUDA was monitored by measuring changes in its specific emission intensity (λex 350 nm and λem(max) 510 nm) that was expected to increase upon complex formation with the protein. Increasing amounts of fatty acids or DAUDA were added to Ag-lbp55, and the samples were equilibrated until a steady emission reading was obtained (usually 5 min). All titration experiments were performed in 10 mm Tris-HCl buffer, pH 7.5, at 20 °C. The concentration of the organic solvent in the final reaction did not exceed 2.5%. In order to minimize inner filter and self-absorption effects, absorbance of the samples at the excitation wavelength was always less than 0.05. Because DAUDA absorbs at the excitation wavelength (λex 350 nm), its emission spectra were corrected for inner filter effects and background fluorescence. All emission spectra were corrected for progressive dilution (≈2.5% maximum) (30Lehrer S.S. Biochemistry. 1971; 10: 3254-3263Crossref PubMed Scopus (1663) Google Scholar).The apparent dissociation constants (Kd) and the maximal fluorescence change upon saturation of the Ag-lbp55-binding site (ΔFmax) were calculated from the experimental data with GraphPad Prism program. The data were analyzed by nonlinear regression and fitted to one-site binding hyperbola, by using Equation 1, ΔFobs=Fmax[L]Kd+[L] (Eq. 1) where ΔFobs is the observed change in the fluorescence and [L] is the ligand concentration.The stoichiometry of the complexes was computed by the Hill Equation 2 (31Monod J. Wyman J. Changeux J.P. J. Mol. Biol. 1965; 12: 88-118Crossref PubMed Scopus (6084) Google Scholar), logΔF1−ΔF=logKd+nHlogL (Eq. 2) if ΔFmax represents saturation of all binding sites then ΔF corresponds to the fraction of full sites at certain ligand concentrations; (1 - ΔF) corresponds to the fraction of empty sites, and nH is the Hill coefficient, which equals 1 if the stoichiometry of the protein-ligand complexes is 1:1.Immunohistology—Antisera against Ag-lbp55 were raised in mice, using a standard immunization protocol (Eurogentec). The preimmune serum was used as a control. Immunolocalization on the light microscopic level was performed as described previously (15Jordanova R. Radoslavov G. Fischer P. Liebau E. Walter R.D. Bankov I. Boteva R. FEBS J. 2005; 272: 180-189Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar, 32Fischer P. Schmetz C. Bandi C. Bonow I. Mand S. Fischer K. Buttner D.W. Exp. Parasitol. 2002; 102: 201-211Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar). Anti-Ag-lbp55 serum was used as primary antibody at dilutions of 1:50 to 1:100. As secondary antibody, goat anti-mouse antibody conjugated with alkaline phosphatase was employed, and Fast Red TR salt (Sigma) was used as the chromogen, whereas hematoxylin acted as the counterstain. For immunolocalization, adult A. galli worms were fixed in either 4% buffered formaldehyde or in 80% ethanol and embedded in paraffin. For comparison with other ascarids or with filarial nematodes, sections of female A. suum and of female O. volvulus, Onchocerca gutturosa, Acanthocheilonema viteae, and Dirofilaria immitis were used.RESULTSProtein Purification—Following gel filtration the native Ag-lbp55 was eluted as a single peak, corresponding to the molecular mass of the monomers, 55 kDa. By using the same procedure, another LBP from A. galli, the 15-kDa NPA representative, Ag-NPA-1, was purified (14Timanova A. Muller S. Marti T. Bankov I. Walter R.D. Eur. J. Biochem. 1999; 261: 569-576Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar, 15Jordanova R. Radoslavov G. Fischer P. Liebau E. Walter R.D. Bankov I. Boteva R. FEBS J. 2005; 272: 180-189Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar). These two proteins show the same biophysical and biochemical features, except that they differ in molecular masses, so their separation was possible by size exclusion chromatography. The binding activity of the eluted peaks was followed with [14C]palmitate, and both proteins showed a high affinity for that ligand (data not shown). The native gel electrophoresis and gel filtration data indicate that under native conditions Ag-lbp55 is a monomer. The SDS-PAGE of the purification steps is shown in Fig. 1A. Moreover, Fig. 1A, lane 1, clearly shows that Ag-lbp55 together with the NPA protein are the most abundant and soluble A. galli proteins.FIGURE 1A, purification of Ag-lbp55 from A. galli, followed by SDS-PAGE. Lane 1, soluble protein fraction after ultracentrifugation (7.9 μg of protein); lane 2, supernatant after 70% saturation with ammonium sulfate (4.3 μg of protein); lane 3, eluted protein fraction after DEAE-cellulose chromatography (1.2 μg of protein); and lane 4, protein after Superdex 75 gel filtration (0.6 μg of protein). Proteins were visualized by Coomassie Blue staining. B, two-dimensional gel electrophoresis of Ag-lbp55. The three isoforms are marked with arrows.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)The two-dimensional gel electrophoresis analysis, in combination with MALDI-TOF analysis, demonstrated the homogeneity of the purified Ag-lbp55 fraction. The two-dimensional gel electrophoresis showed the presence of at least three isoforms with pI values of ∼7.65, 7.7, and 7.8 (Fig. 1B). From the amino acid sequence of Ag-lbp55, the calculated pI is 6.99. The differences between calculated and measured pI values suggest post-translational modifications of the molecules, further supported by the presence of three isoforms. Subsequent proteolytic cleavage, followed by MALDI-TOF analysis of the obtained peptides confirmed that the three bands contain the same protein. These masses correspond to the one obtained from the digested Ag-lbp55 band, loaded on one dimensional SDS-PAGE. The mass spectrum of the tryptically cleaved Ag-lbp55 was compared with known parasitic or mammalian proteins, using the software MASCOT (33Perkins D.N. Pappin D.J. Creasy D.M. Cottrell J.S. Electrophoresis. 1999; 20: 3551-3567Crossref PubMed Scopus (6709) Google Scholar) (www.matrix-science.com), but no homology was observed.Peptide Sequencing—In order to identify the purified protein and obtain some information on its amino acid sequence, N-terminal and internal peptide sequencing were performed. The sequence of the first amino acids of the native protein chain was obtained by direct N-terminal sequencing by Edman degradation and showed no homology with other described proteins. The N-terminal amino acid residue was glutamate and not the expected methionine, which suggested the presence of a signal peptide. In order to get more information about the amino acid sequence, the protein was proteolytically cleaved with trypsin and the endoproteinases Lys-C and Asp-N, and the obtained peptides were sequenced. This approach yielded 35 internal sequences, around 60% of the total protein sequence (TABLE TWO). The mass and the accuracy of most of the sequences were confirmed by mass spectroscopic MALDI-TOF analysis (TABLE TWO). Some of the peptides obtained with different proteases overlapped, allowing identification of the first 35 N-terminal residues. Most interestingly, the amino acid residues at position 32 and 436 could not be identified, due to a post-translational modification. After obtaining the cDNA sequence, these were found to be asparagine residues, and the sites were identified as potential N-glycosylation sites (Figs. 2 and 3).TABLE TWON-terminal sequence of Ag-lbp55 and internal peptide sequences, determinated by Edman degradation The fragments were obtained with proteolytic enzymes Lys-C and Asp-N, and Asp-N, respectively. For most of the peptides MALDI-TOF masses were obtained as well. The main part of the protein sequencing was done by Reinhard Mentele (MPI, Martinsried).
